title: What is the correct order of the second ionisation potential of carbon nitrogen oxygen and fluorine? - Quora

response.answer_text: Carbon—→ 1S2, 2S2, 2P2C+ ——→ 1S2, 2S2, 2P1C2+(Second ionisation)—→ 1S2, 2S2,Need to take out electron from P orbitals that are not full filled. So it requires less energy. Nitrogen—→ 1S2, 2S2, 2P3N+ ——→ 1S2, 2S2, 2P2 (first inoziation of N will be more as we are removing electrons from half filled orbital i.e., 2P which is more stable.)N2+(Second ionisation)—→ 1S2, 2S2,2P1Need to take out electron from P orbitals that are not fully filled. So it requires less energy but when compared to carbon requires more energy as it have more Nuclear charge as compared to carbon. Oxygen—→ 1S2, 2S2, 2P4O+ ——→ 1S2, 2S2, 2P3O2+(Second ionisation)—→ 1S2, 2S2, 2P2 (Second ionziation of O will be much greater as we are removing electrons from half filled orbital i.e., 2P which is more stable.) As a result it has the most second ionization enthalpy. Flourine—→ 1S2, 2S2, 2P5F+ ——→ 1S2, 2S2, 2P4F2+(Second ionisation)—→ 1S2, 2S2, 2P3 the Second ionization enthalpy of F will be less than O because F is getting stable in Second ionization but will be more than C and N because it have more nuclear charge.
